THE SAVING SENSE OF HUMOR.
HERE are certain gifts which are necessary to the writer of poetry or
fiction. These need not he enumerated, since they are of common
knowledge; but among them is one which is seldom recognized as a
need, yet without which no man or woman ever did consistently great work.
This is the sense of humor, or, to put it more clearly for our purpose, the
recognition and appreciatior of the ridiculous.
There have been great writers who have been great and yet lacked the sense
of humor; but this was in despite of such lack. Wordsworth is a conspicuous
example. Had he been possessed of appreciation of the ridiculous, he had never
written "The Idiot Boy- or "We Are Seven"—that apotheosis of the absurdly

THE NEWS—LETTER.

the rest of the book be not open to any blame—though it be possible to bestow
nothing but praise—the one flaw will be remembered when all the beauties are
forgotten.
It is this fact which is especially the tripping stone of women writers.
Some of them, as George Eliot, possess keen sense of humor, and so are saved
from pitfalls; but the majority are unable to appreciate the ridiculous, especially in their own works, and thus are betrayed into absurdities which utterly
invalidate the desired effect of their writings. Often again they are saved from
this by the lack of sense of humor in their readers; but this, though frequently
occurring, is a dangerous dependence. There have been not a few romances
written by the sex which is most romantic but knows least of romance, which
have attained a fleeting popularity solely because the absurdities therein contained have not been patent to the mass of readers; but sooner or later the
author of such work is sure to make a fatal slip which cannot be overlooked,
and then comes the end.
Had certain young lady romancists been possessed of a sense of humor—
hardly, however, to be expected at their tender years—several of the most pop
ular books of the day would not have been written, or at least would have been
written in widely different form. Had a certain popular author been possessed
of a sense of humor, her works of fiction, now read by thousands with intense
pleasure, would never have been submitted to a publisher or given to the
public. But the works were issued, and gained instant and marvelous popularity; and this leads us to another thought—what of the sense of humor in the
public which sets on such work the seal of its approbation? How is it that such
work is received with applause instead of laughter? Have critics and readers,
as well as authors, lost perception of the ridiculous, that such books are confidently issued and implicitly accepted as worthy.
The answer is to be found in the indubitable fact that he who takes himself
seriously will for a time be taken at his own valuation. Self-confidence is
always impressive; there are many literary Pecksniffs who have only to tell us
in impressive style that twice two is four to gain an audience of gaping admirers, and who do tell us these things and are duly admired for their depth of
thought and breadth of knowledge. Had they sense of humor, they would not
inflict upon us their veteran vaporings; had we sense of humor we would not
receive them as prophets and sages; but the sense is lacking in both, and so
the farce goes on.
But we have somewhat wandered from the intended subject of this article,
having been betrayed into generalities where we meant to confine ourselves to
particular examples. And this very lapse illustrates our meaning; for a truer
sense of humor would have held us hack from thus tilting against windmills.
In that last phrase we have found a text for our discourse. Never was a
man more thoroughly destitute of sense of humor than the Knight of La Mancha
and it was this alone which constituted his madness. Being thus destitute, he
saw everything as it was not, and he was led by his illusions into various perilous and ridiculous adventures. Had Don Quixote been an author instead of
a knight-errant, he would have written with as much earnestness as he dis-

^ THE NEWS—LETTER.

3

played in his attempt to redress wrongs, and he would have been betrayed at
every page into extravagances which would have rendered his writings as useless as was his chivalry.
Many are the Don Quixotes of poetry and fiction. For their earnestness and
faith we must needs respect them; but for their absurdities we cannot choose but
laugh at them, and the laughter is our abiding thought of their works. These
are they whose extravagances and absurdities are patent to all save themselves,
Whose earnestness cannot impress because of its patent errors of presentation.
Knights of the Rueful Countenance, they go forth in rusty and ill-fitting armor,
and do not see how grotesque are their figures when they would fain be aweinspiring. And yet, all of us laugh at Don Quixote, but there are some of us
Who love him and laugh with tears of pity not far away, grieving that the noble impulses and high purposes should fail because of fault of method; and so
these earnest writers sometimes win respect for purpose even with the laughter
that greets their mis-directed efforts. But those who have no claim upon our
tolerance because of purpose, and give rise to our laughter by absurdity, win
neither respect nor pity. Of these is that host of writers who write without
knowledge or talent, tellers of monstrous tales, gymnasts of words, who think
to cloak their ignorance and inability by means of a certain ingenuity of incident and phrase, both false to truth. They may have their day of popularity,
these writers; but it will be a short one, and the night will be that of utter forgetfulness,
Lack of sense of humor always shows at last; and its showing is generally
fatal. Examples of recent years are not wanting. Hardy managed to conceal
this defect until he wrote "Jude the Obscure;" then he betrayed himself, and
the result is patent to all those who note the fluctuations of the literary pulse.
Meredith for long years hid his lack of this sense under ponderous phrase and
carefully wrought-out thought; but "Lord Ormonde and His Aminta" convicted
him at last, and, though by many placed at the head of contemporary novelists,
his fame will not increase in the future. Richard Le Gallienne is entirely devoid of sense of humor; only in this fact will his work find excuse, but the fact
will make that work inutile and ineffective. Gissing and Hewlett, Miss
Corelli and Mrs. Ward all lack the saving sense which makes for proportion
and lasting influence; they may enjoy their popularity for a space, but it cannot
last. Sooner or later the public, now hanging admiringly upon their words,
will suddenly find cause for laughter in some extravagance so great that it cannot pass notice; and then the idol will fall from its pedestal.
It is unfortunately true that of late years the reading public has sanctioned
extravagance and absurdity in literature, particularly in poetry and fiction, and
has craved for more; but in this very fact lies the chief peril for those who lack
the saving sense. For there is a fixed line even to the credulity of the public;
pass that, and the public laughs. Sense of humor will define that line and give
safety; without that sense, the line is sure to be over-passed. It is less to know
what the public wants than how much the public will stand; the want may be
created, but the line of toleration cannot be crossed without ruin. The writer
may strut and mouth upon the stage, and still hold his audience; but if he ever
grimace where he thinks to frown impressively, the audience will laugh, and
his spell over them be ended. And then follows hissing mingled with the
G. C. L.
laughter, and the poor mime is driven from the stage.

THE NEWS—LETTER.

IN HONOR OF DR. ROWLAND.
NVITATIONS have been issued for the memorial meeting to the late Prof.
Henry Rowland, which will be held in the Johns Hopkins physical laboratory. The meeting will take place at noon on October 26. The address
of the occasion will be delivered by Dr. T. C. Mendenhall, formerly president
of the Worcester Polytechnic Institute. The Faculty of the University and all
those interested in the life and scientific researches of Dr. Rowland will be invited to attend.

MEMORIAL TO DR. HENRY N. MARTIN.
LARGE bronze tablet to the late Prof. Henry Newell Martin was erected
last week in the corridor of the Johns Hopkins biological laboratory,
which he founded, and over which he presided for many years. The
tablet is set in a heavy frame of dark wood.
A formal unveiling will take place sometime during the coming week.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

5

JOHNS HOPK.INS CLUB.

Z

HE formation of the Johns Hopkins Club is so recent an event that no
detailed account of it seems necessary. But still it might he interesting
to mention briefly the aims which its founders had in mind, and which
they have faithfully tried to realize.
First and foremost, is that of binding all former students of the University,
not only to each other, but also to their Alma Mater. And unless something
does this successfully, the prestige of Johns Hopkins can never remain secure.
Every man it sends out should be an enthusiastic partisan—always loyal, and
always practical. If the club can keep these in touch with their University it
has done a lasting service.
For those who come from other colleges for advanced work the Club has a
special welcome. It balances the tendency to specialize by affording congenial
relaxation and intercourse. Men from each department can become acquainted
with men from the others, and all meet on neutral ground. All are welcome as
individuals, and each stands on his own merits. It is the one place in our fair
land that is entirely exempt from politics in any form or shape, unless, perchance hypothetical discussions about outside affairs take place under its roof!
The significance of this statement will be apparent to all who know the intricacies of a class election, or the "points" that must be possessed by many a man
who "makes" his college athletic teams.
Not only for the graduate student, but also for the members of the faculty
does the Club offer a quiet retreat. It also furnishes an opportunity for the
faculty to mingle with the graduate students, thus increasing the social atmosphere surrounding our teaching staff. Of immense value to the student is this
intimate and different relationship to his leaders, and those of the latter who
wish to make the most of their chance to develope the men who come under them
will desire to enlarge their influence thus.
In these ways the educational value of such a resort is immense, but there
are also other points of view.. In bidding for the support of all J. H. U. men. the
Club offers the neatest and coziest little house in the city,—so close to the
University that distance does not count. There are all the usual facilities for
amusement and recreation, to say nothing of eating and drinking, etc. The
library and reading rooms are comfortable and inviting, and there is an excel
lent billiard table.
The house is always open for inspection, and there will be an enthusiastic
house-warming on Saturday, October 26th, at which the faculty, alumni and
graduate students, will all find a hearty welcome.

R. L. McALL, '00.

FTER the Senior class election, the president of the class spoke a few
words concerning a "policy" for the year. Progressiveness and life
were the keynotes to his remarks, and if proper support is given to the
class officers, each student can anticipate a most pleasant year. A series of
class meetings, to be informally held outside of the University, on Friday or
Saturday evenings, has already been arranged. Seniors—and all other Hopkinsonians—can welcome the prospect of these class reunions, for they will be
a potent factor in unifying the Senior class, and thus exerting powerful influence
in bringing together factions in other classes. Incidentally, we can all have a
"corking good time," and as it is a matter of open house for all, without the
formality of admission tickets, it is to be hoped that all naughty-two will be
present on these occasions. Success along this line means more ambitious
schemes, and success in the more ambitious schemes means real college life at
Hopkins, started by the class of 1902, and kept up by following classes. The
praiseworthiness of this object is apparent.

4

WORD regarding the cancellation of the Hopkins-Princeton game is perhaps in order. Our foot ball team has suffered not a little this year
from lack of material, or, perhaps . we had better say, lack of proper
spirit, for it is certain that there are a number of eligible men, especially in the
Medical School, who, if they chose to take the time, could very easily manage
to devote a few hours a week to foot ball practice. Other men in past years
have found it no hardship to sacrifice a little of their time for the sake of Black
and Blue, and, in the end, have considered themselves repaid by seeing our

gt

_AMIN

THE NEWS-LETTER.

7

University come off victorious. This year, however, much of that spirit appears lacking, for despite the fact that the present Freshman class in the Medical School is larger than ever before the foot ball candidates from it are fewer in
number. During the past week several men have come over and practiced, and
we appreciate and commend their spirit, and wish more would imitate it. Besides this, we had the misfortune, in our first game, to have three of our players disabled. Our team is light, raw, lacking in practice, and without an
organized "scrub" against which it can practice. All these things taken into
consideration, it was deemed most inadvisable to venture against such a team as
Princeton, whose superior weight, discipline, and experience would completely
disorganize our team in its present condition. However, we have still several
weeks in which to constantly improve, and if our men will only come out, and
work with a will, there is every reason to believe that we may end the season
with the Maryland Interconegate League championship banner in our posses
sion.
EPORTS from other colleges that the "lacrosse squad is out for practice"
continually reach us even thus early in the season. This means that
more interest is being shown in the sport, and that the colleges are now
getting to work in earnest trying to develop strong lacrosse teams, where formerly the game was only au experiment. Each year has shown new rivals in
the field, and each year has Hopkins been compelled to play for all she was
worth to keep her laurels. It is true that last year's championship banner does
not adorn our trophy room, but nevertheless the record of the team was one to
be proud of. Hopkins is going to try hard to win back that title this year, and
we must work like trojans to do it, Therefore, when the captain of the lacrosse
team calls for men, all who intend to go out with the team—and may your
numbers be great—begin now. If you are "green" take your stick and ball
and learn to throw and catch; use up all your spare moments by tossing in the
cage, and try in every way to become proficient with the stick. Then when
regular practice commences, you will be ready to learn the game; and the
quicker you learn the game, the better are the prospects for Hopkins lacrosse.
Shall we put out a great lacrosse team, again, as usual? "It's up to you,"

IR

Dear Mr. Editor:
My ambition is to become one of the editors of the NEWS-LKTTER, and, as
I believe that "the early bird catches the worm," I am going to write a letter
right off in the hope of increasing my chances by so doing. I am now a student
of a big University, and am beginning to realize that there are other duties
incumbent upon tue besides cramming like I did when at the preparatory school.
Last Saturday I went out to the foot ball game, and yelled for Johns Hopkins. I certainly think my classmates should show a better college spirit, and
turn out more rooters at the games. I didn't see any of the Faculty members
that I know out there. Do they ever get tickets, or go out to encourage the
attempts to uphold the athletic reputation of Johns Hopkins? They ought to,
oughtn't they?

THE NEWS—LETTER.

8

I think the Juniors are extremely rough at times. They seem to be an illmannered class. Maybe it is because I don't know them. I hear that they are
going to take advantage of us in the cane rush. I reckon there will be lots of
what they call "rough house."
I think Dr. Greene is an awfully nice old man. He seems to have such a
quiet, motherly way about him. He makes its write a lot of papers, though.
I am very fond of writing poetry, and have written several sonnets, which
I consider very good. I may send some in for the next issue. I want you to
see that I am at least making an effort.
I think I shall try for the Glee Club, I have sung for the students upon
several occasions, but not in the University.
I promised my mother and father that I wouldn't learn to drink when I
came to Hopkins. I saw two of our fellows going in Gordon's the other day,
so I turned ray head the other way and walked real fast. I think that's a
terrible habit, and very injurious. Mister McDermot says so.
I'll close now, hoping that my first attempt will meet with a favorite
Your humble servant,
reception.

A FRESHMAN.
We wish to call particular attention to the above letter, because the writer,
though exhibiting a certain pardonable greenness, has, nevertheless some very
good ideas concerning college spirit. We commend his first attempt, and by
hard work and diligence he may secure a position on the paper in the course of
a few years. We would reco imend that his classmates follow his example in
attending the foot ball games, and rooting lustily for Hopkins. After he has
been here a little longer he will learn that our Faculty, with one or two notable
exceptions, have their minds so far elevated above this terrestrial sphere that
they are hardly aware of the existence of college athletics. We also commend
this freshman s noble resolve in shunning "spiritual refreshment." We have
several horrible examples of the effects of the habit in our midst.

DEPARTMENT NOTES.

t

HE Johns Hopkins Biological Department has more graduate students this
season than for many years. There are about a dozen of them, seven or
eight being newly entered.

Prof. E. A. Andrews worked all summer on the Massachusetts coast, not
far from Woods Holl. He was busied with a study of protoplasm. Most of
his work was microscopic, and dealt with marine forms, which he collected
himself.
Dr. Duncan S. Johnson, associate in botany, is still abroad. He has been
studying in the University of Bonn. Before Christmas he will return to Baltimore.
Dr. Caswell Grave, the instructor in zoology, was at Wood's Holl and at
Beaufort at different times during the summer. In addition to his private work

-AMIN

THE NEWS—LETTER.
he also engaged upon studies of the North Carolina oyster for the State of
North Carolina.
Dr. J. E. Duerden, who is curator of the Institute of Jamaica, has been
working in Baltimore all sumtner upon an investigation into the developement
of corals. He brought most of his subjects with him from Jamacia when he
came to study at Johns Hopkins.
Mr. H. F. Perkins brought back with him from the Bahama Islands many
interesting specimens of jelly fishes. He went to collect for purposes of special
study.
Twelve graduates are working in the department of history snd politics.
Among them are Mr. E. J. Benton, who left the University three years ago to
teach in Lafayette, Ind., where he has passed a very successful residence. Mr.
Robert Garrett is another of the number. Mr. J. W. Harry, fellow, has returned to the department.

STUDENT NOTES.
HURSDAY of last week the Glee Club had its first rehearsal of the season.
Many of last year's men came out, and the ranks were further reinforced
by eight or nine aspirants from the entering class; so there seems to be no
lack of material. Members and candidates at present are: Leader, Howard
Eager; first tenors, Eyster, Humrichouse, Carver, Cowles, and Kinnane ;

HOPKINS, 6; M. A. C., 0.

ATURDAY'S game did not bring the expected score of 24-0 or someth
ing
like that. Still, it was a victory for Hopkins,not easily earned,
however.
Sharretts kicked off for Hopkins, and M. A. C., failing in three
downs to
lessen the distance between the pigskin and the goal posts,
punted. From
what followed it seemed that touchdowns by the Black and
Blue would be the
most noticeable feature of the game. Hopkins started by
shoving the oval
between M. A. C.'s tackle and end for appreciable gains;
then Sayler sailed
round left end, and received no hostile embraces until he had
gained ten yards.
Gillespie now circled the other end, and with two good runs
scored the first
touchdown for Hopkins, after the ball had been in play only
about eight minutes. Sayler kicked a goal.
M. A. C. then kicked off, and shortly thereafter Hopkins
had the ball on
M. A. C.'s five yard line again, the main feature of this advanc
e being a thirty
yard dash round left end by Sayler. Sayler then went through
right tackle for
another touchdown, but as it seemed that the Hopkins right
tackle held his
opponent, the ball was brought back and given to M. A. C.
Turner then did the honors for M. A. C. to the extent of
about thirteen
yards, and the ball then went to Hopkins on downs. The Black
and Blue soon
had the oval within easy scoring distance, but were penaliz
ed ten yards for an
off side play, and soon lost the ball on downs. After a short end
run M. A. C.
punted to Sayler, who made a nice start, but had the ill luck
to fumble. Hopkins kept the oval, however,and after a twenty-five yard end
run by Houghton,
the first half ended with the ball on M. A. C.'s forty yard
line.
At the beginning of the second half, Fesmeyer for M. A.
C. sent the ball
whizzing to Yearly, who hugged it, and let himself go as far
as the forty-five
yard line. Houghton and Sharretts then travelled around
the ends for good
gains, but on the next play Hopkins fumbled to M. A. C.
After a few mass
plays, the ball was punted to Bernheim, and soon thereafter
Whipple attempted
a punt for Hopkins, but was blocked by M. A. C. Hopki
ns kept the oval,
however, and by long end runs and mass plays put it within
five yards of
another touchdown. But it was "so far and no farther,"
and the ball again
went over on downs. The pigskin now started the other way
with M. A. C.
behind it, but they lacked about two hours' time for a
touchdown at the rate
they were goiug, and the game was soon over with the
ball on M. A. C.'s
twenty yard line.
Hopkins might have done better; still, she might have done
worse. In the
first half the Black and Blue held together well. in the
second half the team
work was not so good. Fumbles were rather numerous
on our side, but still
worse so on the part of M. A. C. Hopkins needs more
practice in catching
punts, as the work in this line was not quite up to the
notch, also in open
tackling.
One generally encouraging feature, however, during the
season thus far is
the way in which the men help each other, thus playing as
a whole rather than
as individuals. Hopkins has shown great development in
this line in the short

p

MARYLAND INTER-COLLEGIATE MEETING.
HE Maryland Inter-Collegiate Association held its annual meeting at the
Johns Hopkins University last week. After the usual preliminary business of reading reports of officers and committees, the championship was
awarded to the Johns Hopkins University for the base ball, tennis, and track
and field teams. In reality the Hopkins was also entitled to the foot ball
championship, but there was no rule which applied to cases of the tie, and so
the championship was not awarded to any college.
As is well known, the Johns Hopkins team and the team from St. Johns
won the same number of points, but as Hopkins held the championship for the
previous year, it was evident that she was again entitled to it. However there
was no provision for such an emergency, so the championship could not be
awarded to either team.
The athletic committee was instructed to adopt a certain specific set of
track and field events, and to decide where to hold them. The lot fell to the
Western Maryland College, in Westminister. So they will be held there if
convenient, if not, they will take place at the Hopkins. One provision was
adopted which should recommend itself most highly. The relay race will not
be run the same day as the other events, so that the relay men will be fresh,
and in good trim for the trial.
Just before the meeting adjourned the following officers were elected: James
A. Fectig, president, St. Johns; Ronald T. Abercrombie, vice-president, J. H.
U.; Wm. M. Macdermott, secretary, J. H. U.; and Charles A. Hotten, treasurer, Western Maryland.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE MUSICAL CLUBS.
T length the trial of candidates is finished, and the clubs are beginning to
pull together once more. On the whole, the prospect is encouraging,
though there are a few places that are still vacant. More tenors are
needed, and the Mandolin Club could find a place for a good cornetist if one is
available. The schedule of trips is interesting, and should bring the clubs out
at the end of the year with a good surplus and many pleasant memories. Old
Point is once more booked, and the Hopkins Clubs will have the best night of
the week on which to give their concert. So far the schedule is: Johns Hopkins Hospital, November 29; Roland Park, December 6; Hannah More Academy, December 13; Christmas trip; Baltimore Concert, February; Bryn Marr
College, Pa., February; Annapolis; and Easter trip, March 29-April 3. Of
course this schedule is not entirely completed, and, perhap,, certain of these
concerts may not be given, in which case others will be substituted. The
Christmas trip will probably include Winchester, Va., Charleston, W. V.,
Hagerstown and Frederick. Any Hopkins men, graduates, medical school men,
or undergraduates, if musically inclined, are urged to come forward, and aid in
keeping up the reputation that the clubs have won for themselves in previous
years. The trips are delightful, the practice is beneficial, the acquaintances
formed are most pleasant, and the University will be aided by your effort.

UR old rival, Lehigh, has already begun lacrosse practice.

The University of California, which is interesting to Hopkins men because
of Dr. Gilman's former connection with it, is actively engaged in organizing
many student enterprises, and putting finishing touches to those already organ
ized. The large number of men, and the great resources of the Western colleges
inevitably produce success in student undertakings. "California has organized
a rooters' club. Great enthusiasm is reported as a result." A good hint
for us.

Y. M. C. A. NOTES.

t

HE Northfield Echo meeting which was held Tuesday, October 15, in Levering Hall, proved quite a success. It was held for the purpose of telling
those who did not attend the conference about the daily routine while at
Northfield, Mass., and of the great amount of fun to be had out of the ten days
camp life while there. Thrilling tales were told of perilous climbs among the
mountains, and of jolly tramps through the surrounding country. From all accounts, the ten men who represented Hopkins at the conference must have had
a howling good time while partaking daily of wholesome spiritual food. The
delegation promises to be much larger next summer. The expenses of the out-

THE NEWS—LETTER.

15

ing are comparatively small, and the experience is one never to be forgotten.
Among those who spoke of the benefits and pleasures to be derived from attending the conference were: Messrs. Plaggemeyer, Addison, Pagon, Licking,
Wood, Graft. Grove, Edmunds and Freeman. Dean Griffin was an interested
listener at the meeting.
THE AUCTION SALE;
or,
Dog and Freshman.
tNDER the auspices of the Class of 1903, an interesting auction was held
last Thursday in McCoy Hall basement. Just as the nine o'clock period
ended, a young fox terrier appeared, and made himself so popular that
the juniors decided on an auction as the only way of determining who should
be his owner. A dozen Freshmen were eager for the honor of serving the
Juniors. Finally, a long, thin one was picked out, and elevated on a box. To
show his appreciation of the dog's value and his own humbleness, he kneeled
reverently before the animal, muttering odes of praise. Then, to the intense
gratification of the Juniors, who enthusiastically crowded around him, he ran
the bids up to 2S cents; and even more fabulous amounts might have been
offered, had not Mr. Christhilf, bereft and grief-stricken, suddenly appeared to
claim his long-lost pet.
We are glad to notice men of such intelligence and appreciation in the

q

entering class.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
A REGULAR CONTRIBUTOR.

A hot sea-dog whom nothing could phase was sitting alongside the rail of
an Old Dominion liner one day reading the Atlantic Monthly, when a pale-faced
land lubber hailed him and drew rapidly alongside.
Glancing at the periodical in the H. S. D's lap, the new comer remarked
sadly, `Ah,me! I never wrote anything for the Atlantic Monthly, but I am,
nevertheless, contributing to the Atlantic Daily."—Tiger.

J. H. U., P. G.
Dwelling on the heights of Science,
Chewing hash at three a week,
Bidding gaiety defiance,
Ready on the world to wreak
Theories that cannot leak;
Clad in trousers bright high water,
Thus to symbolize a sorter
Elevated tone of life;
Most emphatically rife
With intellect's divinity:
Who can scorn all common strife?
None other than the great P. G.
Whence doth come this great reliance?—
A harder word's not hard to seek—
From living in so close alliance
With clouds upon a lonesome peak?
To Learning has he sworn affiance:
"No thesis to establish! Freak!
Man's chief end you'd surely orter
Grasp. (His grammar's often slaughter)
Et cetera; we'd like to knife
The f— philosopher, but quick relief
Comes in a laugh. Enormously
We smile at him and his belief—
None other than the great P. G.
Prince, the status quo's not one for grief,
Not all the world would just as lief
Consider things so stupidly
As this queer bird and pleasure thief—
None other than the great P. G.
—The Treadmiller.

THE SAVING SENSE OF HUMOR.
HERE are certain gifts which are necessary to the writer of poetry or
fiction. These need not he enumerated, since they are of common
knowledge; but among them is one which is seldom recognized as a
need, yet without which no man or woman ever did consistently great work.
This is the sense of humor, or, to put it more clearly for our purpose, the
recognition and appreciatior of the ridiculous.
There have been great writers who have been great and yet lacked the sense
of humor; but this was in despite of such lack. Wordsworth is a conspicuous
example. Had he been possessed of appreciation of the ridiculous, he had never
written "The Idiot Boy- or "We Are Seven"—that apotheosis of the absurdly

THE NEWS—LETTER.

the rest of the book be not open to any blame—though it be possible to bestow
nothing but praise—the one flaw will be remembered when all the beauties are
forgotten.
It is this fact which is especially the tripping stone of women writers.
Some of them, as George Eliot, possess keen sense of humor, and so are saved
from pitfalls; but the majority are unable to appreciate the ridiculous, especially in their own works, and thus are betrayed into absurdities which utterly
invalidate the desired effect of their writings. Often again they are saved from
this by the lack of sense of humor in their readers; but this, though frequently
occurring, is a dangerous dependence. There have been not a few romances
written by the sex which is most romantic but knows least of romance, which
have attained a fleeting popularity solely because the absurdities therein contained have not been patent to the mass of readers; but sooner or later the
author of such work is sure to make a fatal slip which cannot be overlooked,
and then comes the end.
Had certain young lady romancists been possessed of a sense of humor—
hardly, however, to be expected at their tender years—several of the most pop
ular books of the day would not have been written, or at least would have been
written in widely different form. Had a certain popular author been possessed
of a sense of humor, her works of fiction, now read by thousands with intense
pleasure, would never have been submitted to a publisher or given to the
public. But the works were issued, and gained instant and marvelous popularity; and this leads us to another thought—what of the sense of humor in the
public which sets on such work the seal of its approbation? How is it that such
work is received with applause instead of laughter? Have critics and readers,
as well as authors, lost perception of the ridiculous, that such books are confidently issued and implicitly accepted as worthy.
The answer is to be found in the indubitable fact that he who takes himself
seriously will for a time be taken at his own valuation. Self-confidence is
always impressive; there are many literary Pecksniffs who have only to tell us
in impressive style that twice two is four to gain an audience of gaping admirers, and who do tell us these things and are duly admired for their depth of
thought and breadth of knowledge. Had they sense of humor, they would not
inflict upon us their veteran vaporings; had we sense of humor we would not
receive them as prophets and sages; but the sense is lacking in both, and so
the farce goes on.
But we have somewhat wandered from the intended subject of this article,
having been betrayed into generalities where we meant to confine ourselves to
particular examples. And this very lapse illustrates our meaning; for a truer
sense of humor would have held us hack from thus tilting against windmills.
In that last phrase we have found a text for our discourse. Never was a
man more thoroughly destitute of sense of humor than the Knight of La Mancha
and it was this alone which constituted his madness. Being thus destitute, he
saw everything as it was not, and he was led by his illusions into various perilous and ridiculous adventures. Had Don Quixote been an author instead of
a knight-errant, he would have written with as much earnestness as he dis-

^ THE NEWS—LETTER.

3

played in his attempt to redress wrongs, and he would have been betrayed at
every page into extravagances which would have rendered his writings as useless as was his chivalry.
Many are the Don Quixotes of poetry and fiction. For their earnestness and
faith we must needs respect them; but for their absurdities we cannot choose but
laugh at them, and the laughter is our abiding thought of their works. These
are they whose extravagances and absurdities are patent to all save themselves,
Whose earnestness cannot impress because of its patent errors of presentation.
Knights of the Rueful Countenance, they go forth in rusty and ill-fitting armor,
and do not see how grotesque are their figures when they would fain be aweinspiring. And yet, all of us laugh at Don Quixote, but there are some of us
Who love him and laugh with tears of pity not far away, grieving that the noble impulses and high purposes should fail because of fault of method; and so
these earnest writers sometimes win respect for purpose even with the laughter
that greets their mis-directed efforts. But those who have no claim upon our
tolerance because of purpose, and give rise to our laughter by absurdity, win
neither respect nor pity. Of these is that host of writers who write without
knowledge or talent, tellers of monstrous tales, gymnasts of words, who think
to cloak their ignorance and inability by means of a certain ingenuity of incident and phrase, both false to truth. They may have their day of popularity,
these writers; but it will be a short one, and the night will be that of utter forgetfulness,
Lack of sense of humor always shows at last; and its showing is generally
fatal. Examples of recent years are not wanting. Hardy managed to conceal
this defect until he wrote "Jude the Obscure;" then he betrayed himself, and
the result is patent to all those who note the fluctuations of the literary pulse.
Meredith for long years hid his lack of this sense under ponderous phrase and
carefully wrought-out thought; but "Lord Ormonde and His Aminta" convicted
him at last, and, though by many placed at the head of contemporary novelists,
his fame will not increase in the future. Richard Le Gallienne is entirely devoid of sense of humor; only in this fact will his work find excuse, but the fact
will make that work inutile and ineffective. Gissing and Hewlett, Miss
Corelli and Mrs. Ward all lack the saving sense which makes for proportion
and lasting influence; they may enjoy their popularity for a space, but it cannot
last. Sooner or later the public, now hanging admiringly upon their words,
will suddenly find cause for laughter in some extravagance so great that it cannot pass notice; and then the idol will fall from its pedestal.
It is unfortunately true that of late years the reading public has sanctioned
extravagance and absurdity in literature, particularly in poetry and fiction, and
has craved for more; but in this very fact lies the chief peril for those who lack
the saving sense. For there is a fixed line even to the credulity of the public;
pass that, and the public laughs. Sense of humor will define that line and give
safety; without that sense, the line is sure to be over-passed. It is less to know
what the public wants than how much the public will stand; the want may be
created, but the line of toleration cannot be crossed without ruin. The writer
may strut and mouth upon the stage, and still hold his audience; but if he ever
grimace where he thinks to frown impressively, the audience will laugh, and
his spell over them be ended. And then follows hissing mingled with the
G. C. L.
laughter, and the poor mime is driven from the stage.

JOHNS HOPK.INS CLUB.

Z

HE formation of the Johns Hopkins Club is so recent an event that no
detailed account of it seems necessary. But still it might he interesting
to mention briefly the aims which its founders had in mind, and which
they have faithfully tried to realize.
First and foremost, is that of binding all former students of the University,
not only to each other, but also to their Alma Mater. And unless something
does this successfully, the prestige of Johns Hopkins can never remain secure.
Every man it sends out should be an enthusiastic partisan—always loyal, and
always practical. If the club can keep these in touch with their University it
has done a lasting service.
For those who come from other colleges for advanced work the Club has a
special welcome. It balances the tendency to specialize by affording congenial
relaxation and intercourse. Men from each department can become acquainted
with men from the others, and all meet on neutral ground. All are welcome as
individuals, and each stands on his own merits. It is the one place in our fair
land that is entirely exempt from politics in any form or shape, unless, perchance hypothetical discussions about outside affairs take place under its roof!
The significance of this statement will be apparent to all who know the intricacies of a class election, or the "points" that must be possessed by many a man
who "makes" his college athletic teams.
Not only for the graduate student, but also for the members of the faculty
does the Club offer a quiet retreat. It also furnishes an opportunity for the
faculty to mingle with the graduate students, thus increasing the social atmosphere surrounding our teaching staff. Of immense value to the student is this
intimate and different relationship to his leaders, and those of the latter who
wish to make the most of their chance to develope the men who come under them
will desire to enlarge their influence thus.
In these ways the educational value of such a resort is immense, but there
are also other points of view.. In bidding for the support of all J. H. U. men. the
Club offers the neatest and coziest little house in the city,—so close to the
University that distance does not count. There are all the usual facilities for
amusement and recreation, to say nothing of eating and drinking, etc. The
library and reading rooms are comfortable and inviting, and there is an excel
lent billiard table.
The house is always open for inspection, and there will be an enthusiastic
house-warming on Saturday, October 26th, at which the faculty, alumni and
graduate students, will all find a hearty welcome.

R. L. McALL, '00.

FTER the Senior class election, the president of the class spoke a few
words concerning a "policy" for the year. Progressiveness and life
were the keynotes to his remarks, and if proper support is given to the
class officers, each student can anticipate a most pleasant year. A series of
class meetings, to be informally held outside of the University, on Friday or
Saturday evenings, has already been arranged. Seniors—and all other Hopkinsonians—can welcome the prospect of these class reunions, for they will be
a potent factor in unifying the Senior class, and thus exerting powerful influence
in bringing together factions in other classes. Incidentally, we can all have a
"corking good time," and as it is a matter of open house for all, without the
formality of admission tickets, it is to be hoped that all naughty-two will be
present on these occasions. Success along this line means more ambitious
schemes, and success in the more ambitious schemes means real college life at
Hopkins, started by the class of 1902, and kept up by following classes. The
praiseworthiness of this object is apparent.

WORD regarding the cancellation of the Hopkins-Princeton game is perhaps in order. Our foot ball team has suffered not a little this year
from lack of material, or, perhaps . we had better say, lack of proper
spirit, for it is certain that there are a number of eligible men, especially in the
Medical School, who, if they chose to take the time, could very easily manage
to devote a few hours a week to foot ball practice. Other men in past years
have found it no hardship to sacrifice a little of their time for the sake of Black
and Blue, and, in the end, have considered themselves repaid by seeing our

University come off victorious. This year, however, much of that spirit appears lacking, for despite the fact that the present Freshman class in the Medical School is larger than ever before the foot ball candidates from it are fewer in
number. During the past week several men have come over and practiced, and
we appreciate and commend their spirit, and wish more would imitate it. Besides this, we had the misfortune, in our first game, to have three of our players disabled. Our team is light, raw, lacking in practice, and without an
organized "scrub" against which it can practice. All these things taken into
consideration, it was deemed most inadvisable to venture against such a team as
Princeton, whose superior weight, discipline, and experience would completely
disorganize our team in its present condition. However, we have still several
weeks in which to constantly improve, and if our men will only come out, and
work with a will, there is every reason to believe that we may end the season
with the Maryland Interconegate League championship banner in our posses
sion.
EPORTS from other colleges that the "lacrosse squad is out for practice"
continually reach us even thus early in the season. This means that
more interest is being shown in the sport, and that the colleges are now
getting to work in earnest trying to develop strong lacrosse teams, where formerly the game was only au experiment. Each year has shown new rivals in
the field, and each year has Hopkins been compelled to play for all she was
worth to keep her laurels. It is true that last year's championship banner does
not adorn our trophy room, but nevertheless the record of the team was one to
be proud of. Hopkins is going to try hard to win back that title this year, and
we must work like trojans to do it, Therefore, when the captain of the lacrosse
team calls for men, all who intend to go out with the team—and may your
numbers be great—begin now. If you are "green" take your stick and ball
and learn to throw and catch; use up all your spare moments by tossing in the
cage, and try in every way to become proficient with the stick. Then when
regular practice commences, you will be ready to learn the game; and the
quicker you learn the game, the better are the prospects for Hopkins lacrosse.
Shall we put out a great lacrosse team, again, as usual? "It's up to you,"

Dear Mr. Editor:
My ambition is to become one of the editors of the NEWS-LKTTER, and, as
I believe that "the early bird catches the worm," I am going to write a letter
right off in the hope of increasing my chances by so doing. I am now a student
of a big University, and am beginning to realize that there are other duties
incumbent upon tue besides cramming like I did when at the preparatory school.
Last Saturday I went out to the foot ball game, and yelled for Johns Hopkins. I certainly think my classmates should show a better college spirit, and
turn out more rooters at the games. I didn't see any of the Faculty members
that I know out there. Do they ever get tickets, or go out to encourage the
attempts to uphold the athletic reputation of Johns Hopkins? They ought to,
oughtn't they?

A FRESHMAN.
We wish to call particular attention to the above letter, because the writer,
though exhibiting a certain pardonable greenness, has, nevertheless some very
good ideas concerning college spirit. We commend his first attempt, and by
hard work and diligence he may secure a position on the paper in the course of
a few years. We would reco imend that his classmates follow his example in
attending the foot ball games, and rooting lustily for Hopkins. After he has
been here a little longer he will learn that our Faculty, with one or two notable
exceptions, have their minds so far elevated above this terrestrial sphere that
they are hardly aware of the existence of college athletics. We also commend
this freshman s noble resolve in shunning "spiritual refreshment." We have
several horrible examples of the effects of the habit in our midst.

DEPARTMENT NOTES.

t

HE Johns Hopkins Biological Department has more graduate students this
season than for many years. There are about a dozen of them, seven or
eight being newly entered.

Prof. E. A. Andrews worked all summer on the Massachusetts coast, not
far from Woods Holl. He was busied with a study of protoplasm. Most of
his work was microscopic, and dealt with marine forms, which he collected
himself.
Dr. Duncan S. Johnson, associate in botany, is still abroad. He has been
studying in the University of Bonn. Before Christmas he will return to Baltimore.
Dr. Caswell Grave, the instructor in zoology, was at Wood's Holl and at
Beaufort at different times during the summer. In addition to his private work

-AMIN

THE NEWS—LETTER.
he also engaged upon studies of the North Carolina oyster for the State of
North Carolina.
Dr. J. E. Duerden, who is curator of the Institute of Jamaica, has been
working in Baltimore all sumtner upon an investigation into the developement
of corals. He brought most of his subjects with him from Jamacia when he
came to study at Johns Hopkins.
Mr. H. F. Perkins brought back with him from the Bahama Islands many
interesting specimens of jelly fishes. He went to collect for purposes of special
study.
Twelve graduates are working in the department of history snd politics.
Among them are Mr. E. J. Benton, who left the University three years ago to
teach in Lafayette, Ind., where he has passed a very successful residence. Mr.
Robert Garrett is another of the number. Mr. J. W. Harry, fellow, has returned to the department.

THE NEWS—LETTER.
HOPKINS, 6; M. A. C., 0.

ATURDAY'S game did not bring the expected score of 24-0 or someth
ing
like that. Still, it was a victory for Hopkins,not easily earned,
however.
Sharretts kicked off for Hopkins, and M. A. C., failing in three
downs to
lessen the distance between the pigskin and the goal posts,
punted. From
what followed it seemed that touchdowns by the Black and
Blue would be the
most noticeable feature of the game. Hopkins started by
shoving the oval
between M. A. C.'s tackle and end for appreciable gains;
then Sayler sailed
round left end, and received no hostile embraces until he had
gained ten yards.
Gillespie now circled the other end, and with two good runs
scored the first
touchdown for Hopkins, after the ball had been in play only
about eight minutes. Sayler kicked a goal.
M. A. C. then kicked off, and shortly thereafter Hopkins
had the ball on
M. A. C.'s five yard line again, the main feature of this advanc
e being a thirty
yard dash round left end by Sayler. Sayler then went through
right tackle for
another touchdown, but as it seemed that the Hopkins right
tackle held his
opponent, the ball was brought back and given to M. A. C.
Turner then did the honors for M. A. C. to the extent of
about thirteen
yards, and the ball then went to Hopkins on downs. The Black
and Blue soon
had the oval within easy scoring distance, but were penaliz
ed ten yards for an
off side play, and soon lost the ball on downs. After a short end
run M. A. C.
punted to Sayler, who made a nice start, but had the ill luck
to fumble. Hopkins kept the oval, however,and after a twenty-five yard end
run by Houghton,
the first half ended with the ball on M. A. C.'s forty yard
line.
At the beginning of the second half, Fesmeyer for M. A.
C. sent the ball
whizzing to Yearly, who hugged it, and let himself go as far
as the forty-five
yard line. Houghton and Sharretts then travelled around
the ends for good
gains, but on the next play Hopkins fumbled to M. A. C.
After a few mass
plays, the ball was punted to Bernheim, and soon thereafter
Whipple attempted
a punt for Hopkins, but was blocked by M. A. C. Hopki
ns kept the oval,
however, and by long end runs and mass plays put it within
five yards of
another touchdown. But it was "so far and no farther,"
and the ball again
went over on downs. The pigskin now started the other way
with M. A. C.
behind it, but they lacked about two hours' time for a
touchdown at the rate
they were goiug, and the game was soon over with the
ball on M. A. C.'s
twenty yard line.
Hopkins might have done better; still, she might have done
worse. In the
first half the Black and Blue held together well. in the
second half the team
work was not so good. Fumbles were rather numerous
on our side, but still
worse so on the part of M. A. C. Hopkins needs more
practice in catching
punts, as the work in this line was not quite up to the
notch, also in open
tackling.
One generally encouraging feature, however, during the
season thus far is
the way in which the men help each other, thus playing as
a whole rather than
as individuals. Hopkins has shown great development in
this line in the short

p

time the team has been working. Everything considered, the Black and Blue
has shown up well thus far, and has not yet been defeated. Let us hope that
we shall see the winning banner in our common-room after Western Maryland
and St. Johns have come and gone.

MARYLAND INTER-COLLEGIATE MEETING.
HE Maryland Inter-Collegiate Association held its annual meeting at the
Johns Hopkins University last week. After the usual preliminary business of reading reports of officers and committees, the championship was
awarded to the Johns Hopkins University for the base ball, tennis, and track
and field teams. In reality the Hopkins was also entitled to the foot ball
championship, but there was no rule which applied to cases of the tie, and so
the championship was not awarded to any college.
As is well known, the Johns Hopkins team and the team from St. Johns
won the same number of points, but as Hopkins held the championship for the
previous year, it was evident that she was again entitled to it. However there
was no provision for such an emergency, so the championship could not be
awarded to either team.
The athletic committee was instructed to adopt a certain specific set of
track and field events, and to decide where to hold them. The lot fell to the
Western Maryland College, in Westminister. So they will be held there if
convenient, if not, they will take place at the Hopkins. One provision was
adopted which should recommend itself most highly. The relay race will not
be run the same day as the other events, so that the relay men will be fresh,
and in good trim for the trial.
Just before the meeting adjourned the following officers were elected: James
A. Fectig, president, St. Johns; Ronald T. Abercrombie, vice-president, J. H.
U.; Wm. M. Macdermott, secretary, J. H. U.; and Charles A. Hotten, treasurer, Western Maryland.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE MUSICAL CLUBS.
T length the trial of candidates is finished, and the clubs are beginning to
pull together once more. On the whole, the prospect is encouraging,
though there are a few places that are still vacant. More tenors are
needed, and the Mandolin Club could find a place for a good cornetist if one is
available. The schedule of trips is interesting, and should bring the clubs out
at the end of the year with a good surplus and many pleasant memories. Old
Point is once more booked, and the Hopkins Clubs will have the best night of
the week on which to give their concert. So far the schedule is: Johns Hopkins Hospital, November 29; Roland Park, December 6; Hannah More Academy, December 13; Christmas trip; Baltimore Concert, February; Bryn Marr
College, Pa., February; Annapolis; and Easter trip, March 29-April 3. Of
course this schedule is not entirely completed, and, perhap,, certain of these
concerts may not be given, in which case others will be substituted. The
Christmas trip will probably include Winchester, Va., Charleston, W. V.,
Hagerstown and Frederick. Any Hopkins men, graduates, medical school men,
or undergraduates, if musically inclined, are urged to come forward, and aid in
keeping up the reputation that the clubs have won for themselves in previous
years. The trips are delightful, the practice is beneficial, the acquaintances
formed are most pleasant, and the University will be aided by your effort.

COLLEGE NOTES.
UR old rival, Lehigh, has already begun lacrosse practice.

O

The University of California, which is interesting to Hopkins men because
of Dr. Gilman's former connection with it, is actively engaged in organizing
many student enterprises, and putting finishing touches to those already organ
ized. The large number of men, and the great resources of the Western colleges
inevitably produce success in student undertakings. "California has organized
a rooters' club. Great enthusiasm is reported as a result." A good hint
for us.

Y. M. C. A. NOTES.

t

HE Northfield Echo meeting which was held Tuesday, October 15, in Levering Hall, proved quite a success. It was held for the purpose of telling
those who did not attend the conference about the daily routine while at
Northfield, Mass., and of the great amount of fun to be had out of the ten days
camp life while there. Thrilling tales were told of perilous climbs among the
mountains, and of jolly tramps through the surrounding country. From all accounts, the ten men who represented Hopkins at the conference must have had
a howling good time while partaking daily of wholesome spiritual food. The
delegation promises to be much larger next summer. The expenses of the out-

THE NEWS—LETTER.

15

ing are comparatively small, and the experience is one never to be forgotten.
Among those who spoke of the benefits and pleasures to be derived from attending the conference were: Messrs. Plaggemeyer, Addison, Pagon, Licking,
Wood, Graft. Grove, Edmunds and Freeman. Dean Griffin was an interested
listener at the meeting.
THE AUCTION SALE;
or,
Dog and Freshman.
tNDER the auspices of the Class of 1903, an interesting auction was held
last Thursday in McCoy Hall basement. Just as the nine o'clock period
ended, a young fox terrier appeared, and made himself so popular that
the juniors decided on an auction as the only way of determining who should
be his owner. A dozen Freshmen were eager for the honor of serving the
Juniors. Finally, a long, thin one was picked out, and elevated on a box. To
show his appreciation of the dog's value and his own humbleness, he kneeled
reverently before the animal, muttering odes of praise. Then, to the intense
gratification of the Juniors, who enthusiastically crowded around him, he ran
the bids up to 2S cents; and even more fabulous amounts might have been
offered, had not Mr. Christhilf, bereft and grief-stricken, suddenly appeared to
claim his long-lost pet.
We are glad to notice men of such intelligence and appreciation in the

q

entering class.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
A REGULAR CONTRIBUTOR.

A hot sea-dog whom nothing could phase was sitting alongside the rail of
an Old Dominion liner one day reading the Atlantic Monthly, when a pale-faced
land lubber hailed him and drew rapidly alongside.
Glancing at the periodical in the H. S. D's lap, the new comer remarked
sadly, `Ah,me! I never wrote anything for the Atlantic Monthly, but I am,
nevertheless, contributing to the Atlantic Daily."—Tiger.

J. H. U., P. G.
Dwelling on the heights of Science,
Chewing hash at three a week,
Bidding gaiety defiance,
Ready on the world to wreak
Theories that cannot leak;
Clad in trousers bright high water,
Thus to symbolize a sorter
Elevated tone of life;
Most emphatically rife
With intellect's divinity:
Who can scorn all common strife?
None other than the great P. G.
Whence doth come this great reliance?—
A harder word's not hard to seek—
From living in so close alliance
With clouds upon a lonesome peak?
To Learning has he sworn affiance:
"No thesis to establish! Freak!
Man's chief end you'd surely orter
Grasp. (His grammar's often slaughter)
Et cetera; we'd like to knife
The f— philosopher, but quick relief
Comes in a laugh. Enormously
We smile at him and his belief—
None other than the great P. G.
Prince, the status quo's not one for grief,
Not all the world would just as lief
Consider things so stupidly
As this queer bird and pleasure thief—
None other than the great P. G.
—The Treadmiller.
